description: This collection uses primary sources to explore the 1925 Scopes Trial.

hasPart.name: An excerpt from *Bryan and Darrow at Dayton: the record and documents of the "Bible-evolution trial,”* 1925.
hasPart.text: This excerpt describes the final verdict of the Scopes trial.

hasPart.name: Questions
hasPart.text:
1. Using the [excerpt from *A School History of Tennessee*](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/237) and the [excerpt from *A Civic Biology: Presented in Problems*](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/236), explain why the teaching of evolution in Tennessee schools was a problem.

2. Look at the [image of the defense lawyer Arthur Garfield Hays reading scientists’ testimony](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/239) into the record near a “Read Your Bible” sign. Who do you think may have hung those signs and why? What might be an impact of those signs’ presence during the trial? 

3. In the [record of witness testimony](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/238), why do you think Clarence Darrow, the defense lawyer, asks this student if he still attends church?

4. Look at the [“New Exhibit in the Hall of Fame” political cartoon](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/246). What is the relationship between these animals? What is the cartoon’s commentary on the Scopes Trial?

hasPart.name: Activity
hasPart.text: Divide the class into groups and, using the [record of witness testimony](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/238), have students draft questions for either the defense or prosecution in the Scopes trial. What would they ask the student testifying? What might they ask a scientist? Or Scopes, the teacher?

hasPart.name: Teaching Guide: Exploring the Scopes Trial
Resources
hasPart.text:
1. [Evolution: Scopes Trial](http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/evolution/library/08/2/l_082_01.html), PBS. 

2. [This Day in History: Monkey Trial Begins](http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/monkey-trial-begins), History.com. 

3. [The Scopes Trial](http://nationalhumanitiescenter.org/tserve/twenty/tkeyinfo/tscopes.htm), National Humanities Center. 

4. [Throwback Thursday: The Scopes Trial](http://learning.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/03/26/throwback-thursday-the-scopes-trial/?_r=0), *The New York Times*. 

5. [*Epperson v. Arkansas*](https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/393/97), Cornell University Law School.

hasPart.name: Overview
hasPart.text: The Scopes Trial (sometimes referred to as the Scopes Monkey Trial) was a 1925 legal case which argued whether human evolution could be taught in public schools. A substitute teacher in Dayton, Tennessee, John T. Scopes, was brought to trial for including evolutionary science in his class curriculum. The Scopes Trial was a highly publicized event that brought the conflict between traditionally religious and more modern scientific views to the forefront. This collection of photos, texts, and accounts from the trial help to give a vivid context for the trial itself, as well as the larger issues of science and religion that Scopes’ case brought into question.

name: The Scopes Trial
